title: The official Wombat topic.
content:
Yes. I've been working on Wombat as of late, and it's coming along nicely.

It'll have to be somewhere other than szevvy.com as some chinese guy bought that when it expired and wants US$900 for it, *sigh*, so I'll have to think of a cool new name for my little place on the net.

Stuff that works:
- I've got a lot of the text driver system up and running. I'm hoping it'll be easy to read and use - for example, for Clyde's Revenge the following:[pre] file "c2.db" {&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp packed simple&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned32 fileCount&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp [fileCount] (&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp FileEntry (&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp FixedString name 16&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned32 offset&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned32 size&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp )&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp )&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp }[/pre] works fine as does [pre] file "*.mni" {&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp folder "Fonts"&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned8 tileCount&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned16 unknown #will look at some point&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp image EGA (&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp layout "scanwidth"&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp width 8&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp height 8&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp planes 5&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp transparentPlane 0&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp tilesAcross 25&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp )&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp }[/pre] for Crystal Caves. Still need to do much more work before all games that were supported work, but a lot is done.
This also means that, for example, once you define how an EGA image is stored (as in the example above), Wombat will automagically know how to modify it (it's the reverse of reading it, just a write out of the file tree with some UndrawEGA dropped in)

- Unlzexe is built in
- Hex viewer, should you need it
- Preliminary support for animations, view those as a frame strip, one frame at a time, or animated.
- Mod projects. Still getting there, but allows you to import a game's exe instead of the files. Wombat will import all the game's files, and you can save the resulting project. When you import files, it's saved to the project. Then, when you want, you can write out a patch - which will generate an exe that you distribute. This exe takes care of running the game and patching any files (in memory, no changes are made to the image on disc). I've tested bits of this process and it seems to work for the bits I've tested.
- Fixes for quite a few games already, you find out quite a bit when rewriting all the game drivers.

Any requests?Wombat is my little donation to all the crazy people who do stuff with old games. [url=http://www.szevvy.com]www.szevvy.com[/url]

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content: Rubbish.  This thing will take at least 6 months to take off, and even then there's a lot it won't do.  I suspect any sort of level viewing/editing won't even be in this version as writing a generic, dynamic level viewer/editor is an incredible pain in the ass.  You've got plenty of stuff to do - and besides, there's that many games out there that your XML-based one has a very definite reason to be written.Wombat is my little donation to all the crazy people who do stuff with old games.  [url=http://www.szevvy.com]www.szevvy.com[/url]

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
writing a generic, dynamic level viewer/editor is an incredible pain in the ass

You can say that again. I've got most of the underlying structures sorted out but surprisingly enough the most difficult part is turning out to be the GUI. Using normal 2D window-surface style operations is amazingly slow, so I think I'm going to have to head down the OpenGL track for the map editor (which means I'm probably going to just put it off for even longer [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] )

In fact I'm getting so tired of the GUI I've decided to write a command-line interface to the editor (which now makes it the uhh...fourth user interface to the same core code) which has turned out to be really nice, as it makes testing a lot easier and *really* speeds development (i.e. it's a lot easier to just convert an image to and from a .png file than it is to write a whole image editor.) Unfortunately when it gets to the interactive editors that have no real existing equivalent (map editors, music editors, etc.) I'm gonna have to bite the bullet and do the GUI. But that won't be for a while, at least [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

There is also one thing I have to admit...I have had the code to display Mnoster Bash sprites correctly for well over a year, but Gerald Lidsly asked me not to put it in. I've recently fired off an email asking to able to do so, but have had no reply. As far as I can see, there's only a few sprites that were broken, and they were sprites of little importance. Should I just put them in? I suspect that given there's no software patent on the method used for the sprites, and given that Apogee/3DR owns the IP associated with the code, there shouldn't be a problem, but I'm not 100% sure as to my standing on this one. title: Re: f
content:
Common knowledge rule, that's what I figured too [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Besides, anyone determined enough can just extract the sprites with screenshots, so it's not like we're providing access to something you can't already get.

So did you write the MB sprite code yourself then? It took me a while to figure it out because of the weird bitplane thing. As I understand it, there are multiple bitplanes - normally for EGA graphics you have one for red (4), green (2), blue (1) and intensity (8 ) - four planes total. Sometimes a fifth for transparency or hit testing.

Monster Bash seems to have an arbitrary number of planes, so instead of one for red (bitvalue 4) and another for green (bitvalue 2), you can have a single plane for red *and* green (bit value of 6 [4+2]). I assumed this was some sort of compression, but some images end up larger this way so I don't know - what got me was how you're supposed to combine the image when you get overlapping bitplanes - say one for 6 and one for 2 (red+green and green only.) I can't actually remember what I did now, I think I just combined all the "1" bits into the final image - but it came out properly, I haven't yet found a sprite it doesn't work with [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

Oh, and it's really fun how the image data is byte aligned (so the images are *all* a multiple of eight pixels wide) whereas the image itself might not be a multiple - so if you've got an image that's 10 pixels wide, the image data is actually 16 pixels wide (so you have to decode the image as if it's 16 pixels wide), but you then have to crop off the last six pixels so the final image you present to the user is only 10 pixels wide. That got me for a while, because if you don't realise this, some images are fine (e.g. those that are supposed to be 8,16,24,etc. pixels wide) but for others the image is really badly skewed (to the point where you can't tell what it is, but it has a very distinctive look to it.) Kind of annoying when the same code converts some images perfectly, and others not at all, and you think you've done everything correctly...

Anyway yes, that's enough of my ramblings, ah the fun that goes into writing a game editor [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: f
content:
Do put your ts-bash-sprite file up so I can have a peek at it.

Nah, this wasn't XML based, it was all done in straight C++ (the ts-bash-sprite thing is just a plugin, it's provided by the "Monster Bash" library, so that's mbash.dll under Windows.)

The XML stuff is turning out to be a bit of a nightmare, it gets incredibly complicated once you start doing recursive stuff (like "the offset of this file is equal to the offset of the previous file plus the previous file's size") and it's *really* slow. It's also prone to get stuck in infinite loops when fed an invalid file, but I haven't yet worked out why - so using the XML descriptions for autodetecting file formats is out.

So at the moment the XML stuff is only good for describing group files (files that contain other files, like duke3d.grp, cosmo1.vol, etc.) I haven't even started thinking about things like images yet. The XML itself isn't too bad though, have a look at the currently working XML code to describe [url=http://www.shikadi.net/pckf/c-vol-cosmo.xml]Cosmo's VOL files[/url] if you're curious - but the C++ code is much more complex (it even includes a whole [url=http://spirit.sourceforge.net/]generic language parser[/url] to evaluate the expressions in the XML file. That bit is *very* elegant, but it does add to the overall complexity.)

So I'll be leaving the XML system in, but it's now a much lower priority than it used to be [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: g
content:
My Duke 2 (this is the same as Cosmo, right?) extractor, off the top of my head:

[pre] file name = "*.cmp" {&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp packed simple&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp FileEntry [ size > 0 ] {&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp FixedString name 12&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned32 offset&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned32 size&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp }}[/pre]

[quote]Quote:[hr](like "the offset of this file is equal to the offset of the previous file plus the previous file's size" )[hr][/quote]
What I did for that one is leave the offset out of the driver. The simple extractor looks at the file you're trying to extract, queries for an 'offset' number and finds there is none. It calculates the sum of the sizes of previous files (very quick) plus the offset of the first file (a variable that's calculated every time packed file is first loaded, basically endOfHeader += size every time a file within the packed file is loaded. No recursion [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I'm very impressed by the XML format though, lots of very nice metainfo in there. Looking forward to it.------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: g
content:
Yep, nukem2.cmp is the same as cosmoX.vol. I wanted to avoid coding anything format-specific into the XML parser, which is why I had to resort to recursion. I originally had planned to do something similar to what you mention with the driver realising there's no offset and summing all the sizes, but then I realised that any variation on that system would require modifying the code - e.g. if a format has no offsets, but it does have extra info in between each file, or if the next file starts at a multiple of say 512 bytes (so you have to round up each file size to the nearest multiple of 512 to find out where the next file starts.)

Granted this sort of thing is uncommon at best, but I still wanted the parser to be as generic as possible so you could implement these sorts of schemes without changing the C++ code. That's half the reason why it's become so complex, instead of assuming things and hardcoding those assumptions to keep things simple, I've tried to make it so generic that there are no limits to the formats you can describe, and boy that makes for a *lot* of code [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

- .dds images (DirectX images): added support for 8-bit and DXTN 2-5

Existing games:
7 Cities of Gold ('93) - fixed some more palettes
Captain Comic - fixed errors in sprite colours
Crystal Caves - fonts are now drawn correctly
Duke 2 - sprites are now split up into individual animations
Dune 2 - now drawing intro screens with correct colours
Many games have more extensive sorting, files that were 'other' before are now correctly identified
Many games have corrected sorting - for example, fonts are no longer placed into 'tiles'

New games:
Eve Online
Cars (THQ)------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: g
content:
Current project: compression of Maths Rescue levels. I've fixed the few images that didn't draw correctly (never trust another's image library, it seems...had to make my own PCX handling code). From the initial glance I've given levels, it seems to be a simple type of RLE, but I've got to figure out actor sizes etc before I can try to decompress level data.

Also (I might've mentioned this) but I've cracked the encryption on Death Rally filenames. Once I add support into Wombat for padded blocks ("this thing must take up this much space, leave part padded if need be"), I can start to look at getting the actual files displaying. Chances are, if they went to the trouble of encrypting filenames then the actual data is also protected in some way.------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.

title: Re: g
content:
Szevvy, when I try to open Commander Keen 5 (EGA version 1.4) and 6 (EGA versions 1.4 & 1.5) EGAGRAPH.CK? files, Wombat crashes or gets confused and I can't even close it without terminating its process with the good old Task Manager. Not that I need it, because there's always Modkeen, but it'd be good to be able to see the graphics with Wombat.

Note that this doesn't happen when I open Commander Keen 4 (EGA 1.4 by Apogee) EGAGRAPH file.[hr]SM: "I could go and write a page about the Theory of Relativity (or whatever it's called), but, what is the point if I don't know what the Theory of Relativity is?"

[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/]My website[/url]

title: Re: g
content:
I think the problem there is that I only tested on specific versions on Keen, and I ran on the assumption that all versions of Keen 5 and 6 had the same Huffman tables and tile mapping data, which might not be the case; these are stored in data\keen.dat. The other possible problem is that Wombat might not be detecting whether it's Keen 5 or 6 properly. The issue is that I stupidly didn't back up Wombat 0.4, and the only source I've got is for 0.5 which is clobbered beyond belief, and I thus can't do 'hotfixes'.

Wombat 2 will work differently in regards to Keen - it'll use the Huffman tables etc that are present in the exe itself. So, it'll test the relevant exe to see if it needs to run it through unlzwexe, do so if necessary (unlzwexe and a few other exe unpackers are in-built and automatic for exes), take an MD5 checksum of the result and use a lookup table to determine where to get the data it needs. This way, it'll only work for known versions of Keen, and having the guarantee of using the same data as the exe itself should mean everything works like a dream; hopefully [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] .

So just sit tight for now.------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: Concole support to Wombat
content:
I suspect that the only thing stopping Szevvy from adding support for console games is that there's not much info about them (how do you copy the data off a cartridge onto a PC for instance?)

Speaking for my own game editor, I don't plan on adding support for any non-PC games, but as it will be open source and have a fairly simple plugin architecture, you can easily write a plugin for whatever you want, it doesn't even have to be a game. I think Szevvy was heading in the same direction with Wombat.

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
I have always wondered about that; is it just designed to take the output from a game and convert it into something XP can handle, or is there some box-game interaction?
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
It supports both. You can setup DOSbox to either interpret the code (default, most safe, but also slower), or try and recompile the code to Windows (or Linux or whatever) native code. This makes emulation faster, but apparently more risky.

Well, that's what they say, but I've never had any problems running DOSbox with the dynamic core instead of the normal one.

You can set up tons of DOSbox stuff in [dosbox folder]\dosbox.conf.____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
I don't suppose you've tried both cores on KR's Keen3 mod? I didn't even realise DOSBox *had* a dynamic core...

But yes it's basically an interpreter: "If the next command is 'add one' to AX, then AX = AX + 1" sort of thing. That's why it's so slow, but also why it's (normally) so reliable.

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
Dynamic you say?

I didn't understand any of that, but as I see it, Dosbox can rewrite Keen say into a windows runnable format?
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
If the dynamic core does what I think it does, then when you run something in DOSBox (like Keen for instance) instead of reading each bit of machine code and running it one by one, it will read in blocks of code and "compile" it, so that later on when those bits of code are run, they'll run a *lot* faster.

So it's not something that will magically convert Keen into a Windows program, but then crafting a dosbox.conf and a shortcut will allow you to easily start a Keen episode from a shortcut without any typing, which is sort of like a "Windows runnable format."

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
True, but then you need to have the Keen window and the DOSBox window open at the same time. It's even quicker to create a config file which mounts the Keen directory and runs it, because that also lets you tweak other things just for that game (like the emulation speed, sound quality, etc.) Otherwise with dragging and dropping you're stuck with the defaults.

I imagine that would be what most modders use, because then you can stick a shortcut to it on your Start menu and assign a keyboard shortcut to it, so Ctrl+Alt+F1 could be "play Keen with the changes I just made to my mod" - or maybe that comes when the modding tools are a little more integrated...

title: Re: Console support to Wombat
content:
Update, huzzah!

This is turning into my own personal DNF [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

So...about a month ago I wasn't too happy with how the scripting language worked...so I kinda re-wrote all that. It now compiles scripts into bytecode (like Java) and runs those. The upside is that it's s**t-hot fast, much easier to debug, and the code is easier to read. Things that were broken before and needed hacks to get around them are now fixed, too.

The scripts are also turning out much nicer -

[pre] file name in ("*.bbk", "*.ico", "*.pck" ) is ( ...stuff... )[/pre]as opposed to[pre] file name = "*.bbk" OR "*.ico" OR "*.pck" { ...stuff... }[/pre] - those curly braces always pissed me off. Getting there. I think the way it's going now I'm finally happy with the way it is, about time too! In other news I am the happy owner of szevvy.com again, it works exactly as the .net

-when it's done-------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: Ooh.
content:
Well, it seems something good has happened. I'm actually quite surprised that this is the case, but it saves me a lot of time nonetheless. The source code to read and descramble Jazz 1 sprites has been on the internet, freely available since January 2006. I'm in the process of adding arrays and if-statements to Wombat (which I need anyway for Keen 4-engine games and Pirates 2004), and the result is that Jazz 1 sprites will be supported (will have to look at the palette, but that shouldn't be a big drama).

Why the Jazz community didn't realise the potential of OpenJazz as a source of sprite-ripping info is beyond me.

edit: [img]http://images.szevvy.com/spr.png[/img]------------------

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
I've started working on some docs, got a bit done today:

[url=http://images.szevvy.com/wombat_scripting.pdf]images.szevvy.com/wombat_scripting.pdf[/url]

Ignore the empty pages, and I need to go over it and read it and fix things that made sense in my head but don't on paper [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

It needs italics for comments in the code examples and so forth, but what I'm more worried about is:
1. Is it understandable to some degree or is there too much of something?
2. Is the layout OK or too busy?
3. Are there too many examples?

I personally think it needs more whitespace, and more text to explain things. Perhaps even dividing lines between sections; hmm.------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
It looks good, but I think it would make it clearer if you had a "code" style (e.g. Courier New 10pt) that you used for all code - especially variable names embedded in the descriptive text. For example, you say "...simply skip count bytes in the file." If "count" was in a different style, it would make it clearer that you're referring to the variable, and not that you have really bad grammer [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I think it may also help if you could somehow put the docs into two sections - one for all the explanation, and one as a quick reference for people who know what they're doing but need a reminder. For example, instead of listing all the operators on page...oh yes, page numbers would be good too...well, instead of listing all the operators when you're trying to explain how operators work, you could maybe explain how addition works, and then say "for a list of all available operators, see page X" which is in the quick reference. That way beginners won't be overwhelmed with lots of information, you'll have a complete reference for advanced users, and you won't have to duplicate too much of the documentation.

Anyway, just a few thoughts...![url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
Good points. Will incorporate.------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
Progress update:

The only games that worked in 0.4a that don't work now:

- Duke 2: Works perfectly except for levels - got to add some more script support. The upside is I'll be able to to more decompression code from quite a few games into script, making the whole thing more transparent.
- Dune 2: About 95% done. Palettes are messed up in about 4 images - as you can't refer to data from other packed files from within a packed file...so if I'm drawing an image in intro.pak, I can't use a palette from dune2.pak...yet.

In other good news, all versions of Keen 5, all versions all Keen 4 except the beta/demo, and all versions of Keen 6 except the demo and promo work correctly. Yay.

I've also added an, IMO, pretty nice feature to the hex viewer - I know some people here will like it...the ability to align on non 8-bit boundaries. You can, for example, view all the data in a file as 9-bit numbers to make it easy to find LZW compression, etc.

I'm also working on hooking up level actors in the same way that levels are currently being scripted - and draw the sprites. I'm sure someone here once wanted this for Duke 2; so enemies in a level will draw as proper Duke 2 enemies, etc. There's a few issues I have to get around (making sure that only the first frame is being drawn as opposed to all frames), but it's looking very feasible.

After that...about 35 bugs, and a big spreadsheet of 'things to investigate and things to make better'. *sigh*
------------------
[url=http://www.szevvy.net]www.szevvy.net[/url], for all your Wombat needs. You know you want to.
A member of the LevelLord fan club.

title: Re: The official Wombat topic.
content:
And now for my weekly feature: Vapourware show-and-tell! Behold, the first ever screenshots of the new Wombat...UI needs some work aye.

&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp data unknown[28]
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp levelLayer unsigned16 (

&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp )

&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp )
)[hr][/quote] Zoom out a little...

Bonus image:

Before anyone asks: no, there is no editing. There are other programs for that. You can, however, load Keen into it straight out of a zip and it'll work. No work necessary.
